text:
Today we are hosting
the Climate Symposium at HBS.

The purpose of today's
conference is

really to just put 
everything on the table.
Let's discuss what is happening

in the environment from a 
technology perspective,

from a policy perspective, from
a financing perspective,

bring that information
to the forefront,

and then figure out ways that we can
address this moving forward.

I think this symposium has done
a really great job

of bringing together a huge
diversity of perspectives

for a day of exciting keynote speakers,
panels, learning sessions,
even a startup pitch competition.

In one room, we're talking about
the Global South,

and there's a big focus
on biodiversity.

And then in another room, we
can be talking about
hard-to-decarbonize industries.
We have panels on AI and climate.

Obviously, food and ag is
really important.

But also how we are going
to effectively

finance these projects
in the future.

And I think one of the keynotes
that we heard this morning,

which is really 
inspiring, is that

climate isn't just
a separate function.

Climate is integral to everything
that exists in business.

And so it's become a really
interdisciplinary event.
The theme this year — confronting reality

and celebrating innovation — 
is important becuase

we are in a really 
dire position as a society.

But we also have to 
acknowledge that

there are things that
we can do today

that will really truly make
a difference.
And for us as students, trying to

figure out what role we're
going to play,

it's really imperative for us to get
these different perspectives
to inform our futures too.

Climate Symposium is an event
that's been organized

by the Energy and Environment Club,
the Sustainability Club,

and the Food and Agriculture
Club here at HBS.

This is one of the only conferences
that's a joint effort

between multiple clubs here at
Harvard Business School.

Blending all of these together just
makes for an amazing mix.

If we think of all the
students that want to,

for example, start a
company in climate,
this collaboration is essential.

If we think about the students that
are just trying to think about

how to make an impact
in this space,

bringing all these topics together
is also beneficial for them.

You are now creating these
organic relationships

that occur through your interests
and passions,

and things that are going to extend
hopefully for a lifetime.

What I hope people take away from this
symposium is the inspiration.

I hope that attendees have
struck a good balance

of understanding how dire the
circumstances currently are,

but not feeling discouraged about
their ability to make an impact.

There's optimism out there, and there's
a reason to get involved

and also be successful in their
careers in climate.

There's been some really amazing
innovation in this space,

and we've got a really great team
of people here and beyond

that are working on this
problem together.
